nodes.text: Teacher quality (individual teacher effects) substantially affects elementary student achievement and can be identified using panel data with teacher and student fixed effects

Method: Use panel data from two contiguous New Jersey elementary school districts (1989-90 to 2000-01), nationally standardized NCE test scores in reading and math, student/teacher identifiers, student demographics, teacher credentials, and estimate teacher fixed effects controlling for student fixed effects, classroom variables and school-year effects
Claim: There are large and statistically significant persistent differences in quality across individual teachers (teacher fixed effects matter)

Evidence: Joint F-tests on teacher dummy variables reject equality of teacher effects in all four subject-area regressions (p < 0.001), including robustness to using teachers observed at least three years

Result: Magnitude of teacher effects on nationally standardized scale: a one standard deviation increase in teacher quality raises reading by ~0.20 SD and math by ~0.24 SD (differences between 75th and 25th percentile teachers correspond to ~0.26 SD reading, ~0.31 SD math)
Claim: Teaching experience has a positive and statistically significant effect on reading achievement, after controlling for teacher fixed effects

Result / Evidence: Estimated experience effects (cubic with a ten-year cutoff) imply about 4 NCE point (â‰ˆ0.20 SD) gains in Vocabulary and Reading Comprehension after ten years; math subjects show little or no consistent positive experience gains

Claim: Common classroom variables (class size, classmates' prior average test score, split-level classroom indicators) do not meaningfully predict student test scores once student and teacher fixed effects are included

Evidence: Coefficients on class size, classmates' average past score, and split-level indicators are small and statistically insignificant across subject-area regressions; inclusion/exclusion does not change teacher fixed effects magnitudes
Claim: Teacher effectiveness is positively correlated across subject areas but correlations vary; stronger within math tests and weaker between vocabulary and other subjects

Evidence: Pairwise correlations of estimated teacher fixed effects: vocabulary vs comprehension ~0.27, vocabulary vs math ~0.16-0.32, comprehension vs math ~0.46-0.58, math computation vs math concepts ~0.67; correlations rise modestly when using teachers with >=3 observed classrooms suggesting downward sampling-error bias

Conclusion / Policy implication: Policies to improve student achievement should focus on raising teacher performance (performance-based indicators or rewards) rather than relying solely on observable credentials, since credentials had weak predictive power

Limitation: External validity is limited because data come from only two similar New Jersey districts with above-median socioeconomic status; distribution of teacher quality and policy impacts may differ statewide or nationally

Assumption: Identification requires (a) students observed multi-year so student fixed effects control time-invariant ability, (b) teachers observed with multiple classrooms to identify teacher fixed effects, and (c) an experience functional-form cutoff (ten years) to separate experience from year/school effects
